messages.content: Random thing but is getting a direct spi connection to the motherboard/MCU better than using klipper?
So, I think I have enough things to make a cable
It almost looks like it just has a random SPI port, empty at that

Can't speak to the klipper thing other than I would guess so (no evidence), but SPI does have other potential uses like a SPI camera instead of USB. On my Pi the SPI cameras always performed better than USB, especially when combined with the hardware video encoder.
For klipper, I can't do more than speculate but I assume that SPI would outperform a network socket
Could we use it for better communication? It seems like klipper can't get any details from the board. Maybe running thre stock firmware and this port I can get some more details?
Don't know what the other connector is for tho... Its populated but no silk screen.
Someone more knowledgeable should comment on the capabilities, but would there be enough demand to warrant support considering it requires soldering?
I'm just speaking based on limited knowledge I should shut up
Perhaps. Some other boards you needed to take off a resistor to install klipper/marlin. And a older one you needed to connect a wire for something
You know as much as I do
Good point
There's also another connector with 3 pins just existing
Just empty
Serial?
Backside. Probably not the first time anyone has seen it but we'll I'm just asking stuff
Idk, is 3 pins enough for it?
Not sure. I think it's 4

have you checked out any of these?
https://jbatonnet.github.io/Rinkhals/printers/
https://jbatonnet.github.io/Rinkhals/printers/mainboard-connection/

only had to plug in 3 of the wires

I just want to dump information at this point. I might try to see if can "steal" the updates from the k3

If you're talking about the JST header on the MB, it's connected to the SoC and you can use recovery mode with it.
The JST is USB. The MB needs to be powered by the USB 5V power.
To talk to the MCU it's another path, not sure where to solder or connect for that, but you can do it from the SoC itself
If you want the content of the EMMC (connected to the SoC), the stock updates contain almost all the needed partitions
Userdata and Useremain are not included for example, but the rest is
Would it be a good idea to backup those partitions for possible future recovery?
I did a full backup a few month ago, removed the private stuff and uploaded it here: https://jbatonnet.github.io/Rinkhals/printers/recover-boot-issues/
In the Restore broken partitions section
Well I wanted to dump the memory and look at it to see if I can check of it's similar to the k3 file structure
The MCU memory?
There's that empty connector on the board with 3.3v
The normal memory like all the partitions, sorry
Can you explain this part please?
The EMMC, the backup link contains all the partitions. Or you can have the .img dumps in every stock update

Yeah, in the stock SWU, there are the .img for the EMMC partitions, the app files for the /userdata partition, and the MCU image
The MCU image is then used to flash the MCU itself
Oh, so I don't need to this just to check the updates damn. I still want to see if I can update my MCU with the k3 update image tho

The MCU is the klipper-mcu program. The K3 update .swu is only for the EMMC.
I'm not 100% sure, but I believe this is the klupper MCU image:

Maybe yes.

Update the MCU firmware. To be able to run vanilla klipper better

Okay, so yeah I'm pretty sure the SoC / Linux is able to flash the MCU somehow. Technically I think it would be fairly "easy" to build a vanilla-klipper mcu and flash it.
If klipper has all the drivers (really not sure about that) for the components used in the printer, that could work.
That why I wanted to compare the way the k3 and k2p do it. Since we have a lot more about the k3.
I did think about just trying to flash standard klipper but idk how to configure it. And again the drivers. Is it possible to install extra drivers? Or will it just brick and I'll cry?
I've never touch the MCU part of Klipper. It's surely possible to add more drivers, it's in C or C++ though.

from the photo it does look like it has a different chip for the MCU
Its the only version that even work with rinkhals
Im sorry i thought the MCU was the rockchip chip. Damn sorry
rockchip is the CPU, runs the OS and applications. there are other chips that control the hardware at a lower level, these are the MCU (programmable micro-controllers)
Ah ok, it might be this then. Since the other chip is just memory

the OS loads the MCU programs onto the chips at some point (not during the update), and I think it does this via some system that is likely supported by klipper as well. especially if the chip they use is a clone of a klipper-compatible one
There is support for this familly of chip already in klipper btw
https://www.klipper3d.org/Releases.html#klipper-0120
yes that's what I suspect as well
So i wonder what version is on the printer since even klipper 8 complains its too old. Or maybe i screwed up the printer.cfg

and I think the AC firmware will load its own code to the MCU on boot (if the fw_update/*.bin file is present, which is copied there by an update), so that could be an easy rollback (**disclaimer** I do not know for sure)
I havent bricked it (yet). But if i modify that file, do you think i can inject what i want?
no, at least I don't know how that file is packed

I think it would be better to use a script from the klipper project to load a vanilla MCU code, and somehow prevent/disable the AC method
anyway, I am just brainstorming here. a lot of things would need to be tested/checked first

but I'm going to have dinner now 😋

It checks if a certain file exists, if so it loads it. If not it just uses the version it has already

With this I think i can send a new firmware into the mcu or what ever i really want

it uses a serial `\x03` delimited protocol. if you want to use it interactively, use whconsole.py
see this section: <https://www.klipper3d.org/API_Server.html#request-format>

you can also use this socat based script I made for the WebUI.. a bit less user friendly but works for single commands: <https://github.com/basvd/Rinkhals.WebUI/blob/master/rinkhals-webui/scripts/klippy-command.sh>

klipper/klippy/console.py -v -b 500000 /dev/ttyS1

  This is a debugging console for the Klipper micro-controller.
  In addition to mcu commands, the following artificial commands are
  available:
    DELAY : Send a command at a clock time (eg, "DELAY 9999 get_uptime")
    FLOOD : Send a command many times (eg, "FLOOD 22 .01 get_uptime")
    SUPPRESS : Suppress a response message (eg, "SUPPRESS analog_in_state 4")
    SET   : Create a local variable (eg, "SET myvar 123.4")
    DUMP  : Dump memory (eg, "DUMP 0x12345678 100 32")
    FILEDUMP : Dump to file (eg, "FILEDUMP data.bin 0x12345678 100 32")
    STATS : Report serial statistics
    LIST  : List available mcu commands, local commands, and local variables
    HELP  : Show this text
  All commands also support evaluation by enclosing an expression in { }.
  For example, "reset_step_clock oid=4 clock={clock + freq}".  In addition
  to user defined variables (via the SET command) the following builtin
  variables may be used in expressions:
    clock : The current mcu clock time (as estimated by the host)
    freq  : The mcu clock frequency

messages.content:
A couple of weeks ago I had a mainboard failure  (the one that is in the chamber next to the camera) and I had it replaced with AC service for free here in Ukraine. But I was nearly 2 weeks out of printer while I waited (and if they wouldn't have stripped the board from their own machine it would be even longer). That got me thinking - is there a way to go custom main boards, leaving the print head intact? Or something like that

S1 is my first printer, I'm relatively new to the whole FDM scene and I don't know yet how modular printers are built. Can anyone please weigh in on this?

The board by the camera is the host, like a Pi.
Custom boards would require that everything is replaced.
Are there custom options for the print head boards? Or any custom options at all?
Or in case something goes south the whole printer hardware is useless?

Replacing all the electronics is definitely possible, its been done on some of the Bambu printers with success. It just requires some work.
There are other toolhead boards we can use for that, but the formfactor is different, that might lead to having to redesign parts of the toolhead

Heres a link to Chaz's P1K project, he swapped all the electronics in his Bambu P1S to open source parts and made the printer work without any of the bambu electronics
https://github.com/ChazLayyd/Bambu-Lab-Klipper-Conversion

@Antiriad perhaps it's possible to use pyOCD (https://pyocd.io/) via the tunneled klipper method to access the MCU and dump it. The reason for tunneling is so you can run pyOCD without the limitations of the printer (difficulty installing python binary dependencies)
locate the swd port, use blackmagic probe (exposes a gdb backend) to dump mcu memory and/or set hw breakpoints

so you would have to get access to the controller board anyway
at this point, finding the swd test points might be even easier

hm I think you're right. from my limited understanding you have to set certain pins to low/high to get in boot in a given mode, but if those are not connected to the host CPU then you obviously can't use them
been there a while ago 🙂

the reason why I was/am hoping for a software only method is that I think AC has a way to update MCU code via their firmware updates... but maybe they have added some self-update code to the program on the MCU by which it can overwrite part of its program without going into boot mode
maybe they are just using the smoothieware bootloader
oh, no. mixing things up with the lpcx mcu line
https://www.klipper3d.org/Bootloaders.html#stm32f103-micro-controllers-blue-pill-devices
dfu works only with usb
all the mcu boards are connected via serial only
but your point is valid, they must be able to do that.

the open-source Kobra 3 repo  has this in the MCU code: <https://github.com/ANYCUBIC-3D/Kobra3/blob/main/klipper-mcu/src/otacmd.c>
this is not from vanilla klipper and it looks like a custom MCU update program
but if there is a known bootloader at play here, that might be useful as well
from the looks of it, it is a custom klipper protocol based method to upload an new firwmare image and let the microcontroller flash it after reset
I think so as well. unfortunately it doesn't let us read it, but I assume the MCU binaries can be found in the update.swu files
just writing.
the thing is, if we use this command to load a custom MCU program, but which doesn't include this self-update command, then we could be locked out of changing it again
therefore, have a swd port routed / available for flashing
but... right now there is no real reason to do so.
the firmware on the toolhead and the stepper board is fine. it supports already the custom sensors which are not upstreamed
from the host process / klippy perspective, it does not need to know the hardware sensors, just what api the mcu exposes to abstract the hardware.
one theoretically only needs to adapt klippy and implement missing protocol handling for the accelerometer and the load cell.
fair point, if the MCU program provided by AC has an interface that is compatible with vanilla klipper
the protocol is generic and meant to be extendable
I agree it is much more preferable to make small changes to klippy rather than messing with the MCU. much easier to set up and go back to the original firmware if needed
but I remember @Topes1 (earlier in this channel) was trying to do something with the MCU because it was reporting an old version and klipper wasn't working with it or something
on the other hand, if one picks up the task of backporting those two sensors to vanilla klipper it would make a lot sense to have all software running on the printer in a well understood, open way.

That are the three mainboards/CPUs (RockChip mainboard / Lowerboard MCU for the drivers / Nozzle MCU for the Hotbed/Leveling) without the rest of the printer around it. 😉

Its so crazy how much compute power and the complexity  you have now even in this low/medium budget printers.

My OG Ender-3 printed also fine&stable with a 8-Bit "Arduino Class" CPU with 16MHz and some KB of flash and RAM and good old manual paper-method bed leveling. 😉

And now is a 32Bit 1.4Ghz SoC with 256MB, 8GB Flash plus  2 x 72MHz CPUs for stepper-driver and Extruder control necessary (and even that seems to be not enough "power" to run the printer stable).
wait so did you just pulll everything out of the printer to get better access to the components for modding or are these all your own boards?
